description: A spell used to open doors; it is probably related to Alohamora.

The Summoning Charm (Accio) allows the caster to summon objects toward themselves, either in direct line of sight or out of view, by calling the object's name aloud after the incantation (unless cast nonverbally). Successful casting requires the caster to have a clear mental image of the object. The charm's opposite is the Banishing Charm.
pronunciation: Various, including: AK-ee-oh, AK-see-oh, AS-see-oh (US), and AT-chee-oh (Anglo-Catholic pronunciation)
effect: Summons an object from a distance
origin: The Latin word accio means "I call" or "I summon".
notes: The Summoning Charm could not be used on buildings. In addition, it did not work on most living things, and those few on which it did were generally not considered worth Summoning, such as flobberworms.

description: Produces a clean, drinkable jet of water from the wand tip.
origin: Derived from Latin 'aqua' meaning 'water' and 'menti', likely referring to 'mind'.
notes: This spell can be used to extinguish fires, hydrate people, or fill containers with water.

description: Unlocks objects such as doors and windows.
effect: Unlocks locks on doors or windows
origin: From the West African Sidiki dialect meaning 'friendly to thieves'.
notes: Cannot unlock magically protected locks.

description: Clears someone's airway if they are choking.
notes: Useful for first-aid situations.

description: Reveals hidden or invisible messages, particularly those written in invisible ink.
notes: Often used to read hidden or enchanted texts.

description: Allows a witch or wizard to teleport instantly to another location. Disapparating is the opposite.
effect: Transports the caster instantly to another place
notes: Requires a license and is risky if performed improperly.

description: Lifts the caster high into the air. The charm also works underwater, propelling the caster above the surface.
notes: Useful for escaping from underwater or low places.

description: Also known as The Killing Curse, one of the three Unforgivable Curses. Causes instant death without physical harm.
origin: Aramaic phrase 'Avada Kedavra' meaning 'let this thing be destroyed'.
notes: Harry Potter is the only known survivor of this curse.

description: Conjures a flock of birds from the tip of the wand. When used in conjunction with Oppugno, it can be used offensively.
effect: Creates a flock of small birds
notes: Primarily used for entertainment or distraction.

description: Transforms the target's bogeys into large bats that fly out of the victim's nose. It was invented by Miranda Goshawk.
effect: Transformed target's bogeys into bats that flew out of the victim's nose

description: The exact effects of the spell are unknown, though it presumably is of damaging nature and it produces a bolt of white light from the tip of the wand.
Transforms the target's bogeys into large bats that fly out of the victim's nose. It was invented by Miranda Goshawk.
Known as the Extension Charm, it greatly expands or extends the capacity of an object or space without affecting its external dimensions.
effect: Increases the internal space of an object
origin: Latin 'capacious' meaning 'capable of holding much' and 'extremis' meaning 'utmost'.
notes: Commonly used on bags to carry large amounts of items.

description: Known as the Confundus Charm, it causes confusion in the target, making them disoriented or easily tricked.
notes: Often used in duels or to disorient opponents.

description: Affects the eyes and sight of the target, causing discomfort and impaired vision.
notes: Effective against creatures with sensitive vision.

description: Changes the hair color and style of the target.
notes: Often used for temporary changes in appearance.

description: One of the three Unforgivable Curses, it inflicts unbearable pain on the target without causing physical harm.
notes: One of the most feared spells, as it causes immense suffering.

description: Used to precisely cut or sever an object, allowing the caster to slice or divide materials accurately.
notes: Commonly used in tailoring, gardening, or to free objects.

description: Causes the target to blend into their surroundings, creating a chameleon-like effect.
effect: Makes the target appear invisible or camouflaged
notes: Useful for stealth, but requires concentration to maintain.

description: A non-verbal transportation spell that allows a witch or wizard to vanish from one location and reappear at another. Apparate is the opposite.
effect: Transports the caster instantly away from a place
notes: Requires a license and is risky if performed improperly.

description: Causes rapid growth in the targeted object, making it expand to many times its original size.
origin: Derived from 'engorge', meaning to swell with fluid.
notes: Overuse can lead to unstable results and is hard to reverse.

description: The Patronus Charm creates a powerful projection of hope and happiness, which repels Dementors. A corporeal Patronus takes the shape of an animal representing the caster, while a non-corporeal Patronus appears as a wisp of light.
effect: Summons a Patronus to protect against dark creatures
notes: Harry Potter was the youngest known wizard to cast a corporeal Patronus at age 13.

description: Allows a witch or wizard to build or set up a structure, such as a tent.
notes: Commonly used for setting up camps or temporary structures.

description: Vanishes objects, making them disappear completely.
notes: Usually requires some skill to make objects reappear after vanishing.

description: The Disarming Charm, used to force an opponent to drop whatever they are holding. Often used in duels.
origin: Latin 'expellere' meaning 'to drive out' and 'arma' meaning 'weapon'.
notes: Known as Harry Potter's signature spell.

description: A healing charm that conjures bandages and wraps to dress wounds.
origin: Latin 'ferula' meaning 'splint' or 'rod used in healing'.
notes: Primarily used in first aid situations to stabilize injuries.

description: A complex and advanced charm that conceals a secret within the soul of a chosen 'Secret Keeper.' The secret, such as a location, becomes undetectable to everyone else.
effect: Conceals a secret within a chosen individual
notes: One of the most powerful concealment spells in the wizarding world.

description: Conjures destructive and enchanted flames that are extremely difficult to control and can consume anything in their path.
notes: Highly dangerous and used only in extreme circumstances; difficult to extinguish.

description: A general counter-spell used to reverse or halt the effects of other spells that are already in effect.
origin: Latin 'finire' meaning 'to end' and 'incantatem' relating to 'incantation'.
notes: Useful in duels or emergencies to counter ongoing magical effects.

description: The Doubling Charm, used to duplicate an object, creating an exact copy.
notes: While it duplicates objects, it can cause complications with enchanted items.

description: Transforms a staircase into a smooth slide, allowing quick descent.
effect: Creates a slide from a staircase
notes: Commonly used in emergencies for rapid escape.

description: A charm that reveals the presence of another person nearby, often used to detect hidden individuals.
notes: Particularly useful for locating people in an area.

description: A spell that detects anyone's true identity and location on a piece of parchment, famously used in the creation of the Marauder's Map.
effect: Shows the identity and location of individuals on a map
notes: This charm is highly complex and used to track people within a specific area.

description: Immobilizes living targets, preventing them from moving.
notes: Useful for stopping creatures temporarily.

description: A jinx that temporarily slows or halts the movement of the target.
notes: Commonly used in dueling to gain an advantage.

description: One of the three Unforgivable Curses, it places the target under the complete control of the caster, forcing them to follow commands.
effect: Gives the caster control over the target
notes: Illegal and punishable by life imprisonment in Azkaban.

description: Makes an object waterproof or resistant to outside substances.
notes: Commonly used on glasses and clothing in wet environments.

description: Conjures flames, igniting objects or setting a target on fire.
notes: Useful for both practical and defensive purposes.

description: Causes the target's tongue to stick to the roof of their mouth, preventing speech.
notes: Useful for silencing others temporarily.

description: A spell that allows the caster to invade or navigate another person's mind, often used to read thoughts and memories.
effect: Allows mind reading and navigation of thoughts
notes: Highly advanced and often invasive; requires considerable skill.

description: Levitates the target by their ankle, often used as a prank to dangle individuals upside down.
effect: Lifts the target by their ankle
notes: Can be countered by 'Liberacorpus.'

description: The Leg-Locker Curse binds the target's legs together, preventing them from walking.
notes: Often used in dueling to immobilize opponents.

description: A spell that illuminates the caster's wand, allowing them to see in dark places.
effect: Produces light from the caster’s wand
notes: One of the most commonly used charms for visibility in the dark.

description: Conjures and projects Lord Voldemort's Dark Mark into the sky, signaling his followers.
notes: A symbol of fear and allegiance to Voldemort; often used during Death Eater attacks.

description: Inflicts an extreme runny nose or cold on the target, causing discomfort.
origin: Latin 'mucus' meaning 'mucus' and 'ad nauseam' meaning 'to sickness'.
notes: More of a prank than a serious spell.

description: Creates a buzzing sound in the target's ears, preventing them from overhearing conversations.
notes: Useful for private conversations in public places.
